10.06.text: Evolution is the development of life on Earth.

13.81.text: This is a process that began billions of years ago and is still continuing to this day.

20.06.text: Evolution tells us how it was possible for the enormous diversity of life to develop.

25.53.text: It shows us how primitive Protozoa could become the millions of different species that we see today.

33.83.text: Evolution, then, is the answer to the question that we have all asked on seeing a Daschund and a Great Dane together:

42.50.text: how is it possible for ancestors to have descendants that look so very different to them?

50.31.text: In answering this question, we want to focus on animals, excluding other forms of life such as fungi and plants.

57.93.text: The first question to ask is therefore: how can one animal develop into a whole new species of animal?

64.85.text: Ah, but just a quick question: what exactly is a species?

71.89.text: A species is a community of animals that is capable of producing offspring with one another,

77.19.text: with those offspring also being capable of reproducing in turn.

82.23.text: To understand this answer better, we need to take a closer look at the following points:

86.40.text: the uniqueness of living creatures, guaranteed through the excess production of offspring and heredity,

93.98.text: and as a second key point, selection.

97.77.text: Let's begin with uniqueness. Every creature that exists is unique, and this is essential for evolution.

107.56.text: The members of a species may strongly resemble each other in appearance;

111.19.text: however, they all have slightly different traits and characteristics.

115.52.text: They may be a bit bigger, fatter, stronger, or bolder than their fellow animals.

121.52.text: So, what is the reason for these differences? Let's take a closer look at a creature.

128.23.text: Every creature is made up of cells. These cells have a nucleus.

133.73.text: The nucleus contains the chromosomes, and the chromosomes hold the DNA.

141.56.text: DNA consists of different genes, and it's these genes that are life's information carriers.

148.49.text: They contain instructions and orders for the cells, and determine the characteristics and traits that living creatures have,

156.75.text: and it's precisely this DNA that is unique to every creature.

162.06.text: It's slightly different from individual to individual, which is why each has slightly different characteristics.

169.57.text: But how is the enormous range of DNA created?

175.13.text: One key factor is the excess production of offspring.

179.57.text: In nature, we can observe that creatures generally produce far more offspring than is necessary

184.36.text: for the survival of their species, with many offspring dying an early death as a result.

189.55.text: Often there are even more offspring than the environment in which they live is able to support.

194.02.text: This is one factor in increasing diversity within a species.

197.61.text: The more offspring that are produced, the more little differences occur,

202.11.text: and this is what nature wants: as many little differences as possible.

208.80.text: The second major cause of the uniqueness of individuals occurs in heredity itself.

215.14.text: By the way, heredity means the passing on of DNA to offspring.

222.30.text: Two very interesting factors come into play in this process: recombination and mutation.

229.97.text: Recombination is the random mixing of the DNA of two creatures.

234.89.text: When two creatures fall in love and mate, they recombine their genes twice.

241.47.text: The first time, they do this separately when they generate the gametes - that is, sperm and egg cells.

248.30.text: The gametes take half of the genes and shuffle them.

253.86.text: The second recombination occurs when a male inseminates a female.

258.55.text: The parents each provide 50% of their DNA, in other words, 50% of their unique traits and characteristics.

268.67.text: These are then recombined, or mixed, and the result is new offspring.

273.55.text: These offspring have a random mix of the DNA, and therefore the traits and characteristics of their parents.

281.03.text: This increases the diversity and differences within a species even further,

287.45.text: but mutations are also important for evolution.

292.29.text: Mutations are random changes in DNA.

295.65.text: These can also be described as copying errors within the DNA,

300.36.text: triggered by toxins or other chemical substances, or by radiation.

305.21.text: A mutation exists when part of the DNA is altered.

309.87.text: These changes are often negative, and may result in illnesses such as cancer.

315.90.text: However, they may also have neutral or positive effects,

320.15.text: such as the blue eye colour in humans, which is one such random mutation.

326.19.text: In all cases, a mutation has to affect a gamete, that is a sperm or egg cell,

332.24.text: because only the DNA in the gametes is passed on to the offspring.

337.82.text: This is also the reason why we protect our sexual organs during x-rays, whilst other parts of the body are not at risk.

345.49.text: In summary then, in the heredity process, creatures pass on their characteristics to their offspring in the form of DNA.

353.66.text: Recombination and mutation change the DNA so that each child looks different to its siblings,

359.36.text: and receives a random mix of the characteristics of its parents.

365.08.text: There's a key word here: random.

370.22.text: All of these processes are based on chance.

373.78.text: Random recombination and mutations result in individuals with random mixes of traits and characteristics,

379.61.text: which in turn mix these randomly, and pass them on.

384.03.text: But how can so much be down to chance, when all living creatures are so perfectly adapted to their environment,

391.86.text: for example, the stick insect, the hummingbird, and the frogfish?

399.32.text: The answer is provided by the second key point: selection.

403.82.text: Each individual is subjected to a process of natural selection.

409.48.text: As we have learned, each individual is somewhat different to its fellows,

413.74.text: and there is extensive variation within a species.

420.52.text: Environmental influences have an effect on living creatures. These so-called selection factors include:

426.02.text: predators, parasites, animals of the same species, toxins, changes in habitat, or the climate.

435.32.text: Selection is a process that each individual is subjected to.

438.78.text: Every creature has a unique mix of traits and characteristics.

443.02.text: This mix helps them to survive in their environment, or not, as the case may be.

451.78.text: Anyone with an unsuitable mix will be selected from the environment.

459.35.text: Those with the right mix survive, and can pass on their enhanced traits and characteristics.

467.33.text: This is why diversity is so important.

470.24.text: This is why creatures make so much effort to produce offspring that are as different as possible.

476.48.text: They increase the likelihood that at least one of their offspring passes nature's selection process.

481.89.text: They maximize their chances of survival.

485.34.text: A good example of this can be seen in a group of finches living on a remote island.

490.92.text: They are some of the most famous animals in the world of science,

494.59.text: and are known as Darwin finches, after their discoverer, Charles Darwin, and this is the story of those finches.

503.09.text: A few hundred years ago, a small group of finches was blown onto the Galapagos Islands in the middle of the Pacific, probably by a big storm.

512.98.text: The finches found themselves in an environment that was completely new to them,

516.92.text: a real finch paradise: an abundance of food and no predators.

522.23.text: They reproduced rapidly and numerously. The islands were soon heaving with finches.

528.06.text: This meant that food supplies became increasingly scarce.

531.25.text: The finch paradise was threatened with famine, and finch friends became competitors.

539.39.text: Their individuality and small differences, in this case their slightly different beaks,

543.48.text: meant that some of the birds were able to avoid competing with their fellow finches.

550.82.text: The beaks of some of the finches were more suitable for digging for worms.

556.19.text: Other finches were able to use their beaks better for cracking seeds.

561.22.text: The finches consequently sort out ecological niches. In these niches, they were safe from excessive competition.

568.38.text: They soon began to mate primarily with other finches that used the same niche.

572.69.text: Over the course of many generations, these characteristics were enhanced,

577.22.text: enabling the finches to exploit their niches successfully.

580.94.text: The differences between the worm-diggers and the seed-crackers became so large

585.80.text: that they were no longer able to mate with one another. Different species emerged as a result.

592.10.text: Today, there are 14 different species of finch living on the Galapagos Islands,

597.94.text: all of which are descended from the same group of stranded finches.

602.02.text: This is how new species are created by evolution:

605.88.text: through the interaction of unique individuals,

620.47.text: It tells us where the variety of life comes from, and why living creatures are so perfectly adapted to their habitats.

627.64.text: But it also effects us personally.

630.36.text: Every person is the result of 3.5 billion years of evolution, and that includes you.

637.22.text: Your ancestors fought and adapted in order to survive.

641.20.text: This survival was an extremely uncertain thing.

645.55.text: If we consider the fact that 99% of all the species that have ever lived are extinct,

649.97.text: then you can consider yourself part of a success story.

655.69.text: The dinosaurs have disappeared, but you are alive, watching this video,

659.77.text: because you're incredibly special, just like all the other creatures that exist today:

666.30.text: irreproducible and unique in the universe.
